item.title: Parallel List Ranking - Helman & JaJa
item.description: Recently I implemented a list ranking algorithm “Designing Practical Efficient Algorithms for Symmetric Multiprocessors” by Helman & JaJa, in my OMSCS course Intro to High Performance Computing. The paper can be downloaded here.

item.title: Nordic NRF52840 Storage Part II
item.description: This post is the continued talk about the persistent storage for Nordic nRF52840. In part I we went over using the Flash Data Storage (FDS) library. In this part II, I’ll be discussing another import component, user information configuration registers (UICR).

item.title: Nordic NRF52840 Storage Part I
item.description: There are mainly two ways for persistent storage of data in NRF52840: flash and UICR. I’ll be discussing the flash mainly in this part I, and UICR in part II.

item.title: Nordic BLE Advertising Part I
item.description: Nordic has a good tutorial Bluetooth low energy Advertising, a beginner’s tutorial, and two guides of GAP advertising Part I and Part II. In this post, we will go through some of advertising features in details.

item.title: Nordic BLE Serial
item.description: The nRF Serial Port Library is designed as a more sophisticated replacement for the app_uart module, as pointed out at the library’s page, there are many advantages of this module over app_uart:

item.title: Merge Nordic Buttonless DFU with NUS
item.description: Nordic provides good examples, but mostly independent from each other. To make a BLE UART service with DFU support, we’ll need to merge the two examples:

item.title: Nordic BLE Device Firmware Update Bootloader
item.description: Noric provides detailed documentations of Bootloader and DFU modules

item.title: iMX8M Mini with AOSP Beginner Part 1
item.description: I recently got an NXP i.MX 8M Mini EVK board. It has rather powerful Arm Cortex-A53, Cortex-M4, Audio, Voice and Video processors. As a total newbie with no previous experiences on Android Operation System Project (AOSP) or NXP iMX series, this post records my first hands-on.

item.title: Nordic BLE development with SES and VS code in Ubuntu
item.description: The nRF5 series of Bluetooth low energy chip is a very popular platform from Nordic Semiconductor. Currently there are four IDEs with compiler supported by Nordic, however, for Linux users there are only two options available: SEGGER Embedded Studio (SES) and GNU/GCC.
